title: ISO 50001:2018 - Elements of Energy Management System (EnMS)
headline: Learn how to meet the requirements of the latest ISO 50001:2018 (EnMS) Standard with this free online ISO 50001 course.
description: This free online ISO 50001 certification training course teaches the fundamental elements of Energy Management Systems (EnMS). You will study the latest ISO 50001 standard including its regulation and look into the relation of ISO 140001:2015 with ISO 50001:2018. You will learn how companies can manage their energy performance and energy management system as well as why energy management and optimization is the challenge of the new century.

courseDescription:
ISO 50001:2018 is the second edition of ISO 50001 standard, and it is titled "Energy management systems — Requirements with guidance for use". The updated standard explains the requirements for an energy management system (EnMS) where an organization can demonstrate its capability to manage its energy performance and improve its Energy management system so that the organization can fulfil its business goals and relevant regulatory requirements consistently. ISO 50001:2018 can also be utilized by organizations such as vendors or external parties who offer services or products, to big corporate organizations. So it is applicable to all types of organizations. 

This course begins by covering the context of the publication of this ISO standard, and reviews the various existing philosophies related to Energy management such as Building Energy Management System, Energy Measuring and Information system and their differences with Energy Management System (EnMS) itself. Then the course highlights important terminology which is grouped under different headings to help students understand the concepts easily. The course explains all the requirements of ISO 50001 including specific requirements of the energy management system, leadership responsibilities along with resource management, requirements of system realization such as Context of Organization, EnMS planning, support functions, Operations, facilities and equipment design for EnMS, procurement controls for EnMS etc. The course also covers the Clause - 9 and Clause - 10 of ISO 50001 standard as a separate module that explains all about measurement, monitoring, analysis, evaluation and improvement.

If you’re interested working in the energy sector as a future career, or if you’re an ISO professional seeking to keep up to date with the latest ISO 50001 standard, then this clear and simple course is for you. Understanding ISO 50001:2018 is of vital importance for all professionals working in the compliance as well as energy sector. So, start this free online course today and in just 3 hours you’ll be up to date with the new changes in this important ISO standard.

Start Course Now

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module explains the existing relevant standards and regulation for energy management system - EnMS and also the two different edition. It also presents some important terminologies with related definitions as defined by ISO 50001; which are arranged to help you understand well. It also provides a comparison of two editions of ISO 50001:2018 and ISO 50001:2011. Moreover, it also discusses the relation of ISo 140001:2015 with ISO 50001:2018.
topics: Fundamentals of Energy Management System (EnMS) - Learning Outcomes
Important Terminologies of the Energy Management System (EnMS)
Essential Provisions of the Energy Management System (EnMS)
Fundamentals of Energy Management System (EnMS) - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Planning and Operations of Energy Management System
modules.description: This module explains the planning and operational components of the Energy Management System (EnMS) as per ISO 50001:2018. Planning part includes Context of Organization, Leadership whereas the Operation part includes Support and Operation Controls of the EnMS. Within Support there are various requirements on resources, comptence, communication and documented information. Within Operations, there are different requirements on Operation Controls, Design of facility and equipment, and Procurement.
topics: Planning and Operations of Energy Management System - Learning Outcomes
Planning and Operations of Energy Management System - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, Clause - 9 and Clause - 10 of the ISO 50001:2018 standard is taught. Clause - 8 specifies the general requirements, management of monitoring and measurement issues, nonconforming product management, data analysis etc. Within this clause - 10, Clause - 10.2 is on continual improvement which paves out ways for the organization to improve its energy system and energy performance through the framework of non-conformity and corrective actions.
topics: Analysis, Evaluation and Improvement - Learning Outcomes
Continual Improvement of Energy Management System (EnMS)
Analysis, Evaluation and Improvement - Lesson Summary

• After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Define the role of the Energy Management System (EnMS). 
    • Narrate the differences between EnMS versus EMIS and how they can complement each other.
    • Explain the framework of ISO 50001 and its Benefits.
    • Examine the changes in ISO 50001:2018 from the earlier edition. 
    • Define the Energy-related and EnMS Terminologies in ISO 50001:2018.
    • Compare the difference between Energy Baseline (EnB) and Energy Performance Indicators (EnPIs). 
    • State the definitions of Terminologies related to Energy Performance and other Technicalities.
    • Describe the role of the Environmental Management System versus the Energy Management System.
    • Explain the PDCA (Plan-do-check-Act) model in ISO 50001:2018.
    • List the important provisions of ISO 50001:2018 covering all auditable clauses.

  • What is meant by the Energy Management System (EnMS)?
  • Energy Management System (EnMS) is often interpreted differently. Some professionals consider an energy data analysis system or a building energy management system for equipment operational efficiency as EnMS which is not the case. The energy data analysis system or the building energy management system can be a part of an overall Energy Management System but it is not an energy management system on its own. The term energy management is a wider term that encompasses BEMS, EMIS and lot of other management elements within it.

    BEMS
    • The building energy management system is often referred to as BMS/BEMS. 
  • EMIS
    • The analysis and monitoring system for energy is known as Energy Management Information System (EMIS). 
  • EnMS
    • EnMS is a management system that empowers organizations to plan, review, improve, and identify for the energy consumption patterns in an organization.

    • Energy is defined as per clause 3.5.1 as "electricity, fuels, steam, heat, compressed air and other similar media".

      Some of the examples are fuels, steam, heat, electricity, compressed air and other similar media.

      It is important to note here that for the implementation of this standard, energy refers to the numerous types of energy, including renewable, which can be procured, stored, treated, used in equipment or in a process, or recovered.

    • Energy use is defined as per clause 3.5.4 as "application of energy.”

      Examples are lighting, ventilation, heating, cooling, transportation, data storage, production process. It is important to note that Energy use is also referred to as “energy end-use”.

      Energy consumption is defined as per clause 3.5.2 as "quantity of energy applied".

    • Energy efficiency is defined as per clause 3.5.3 as "ratio or other quantitative relationship between outputs of performance, service, goods, commodities, or energy, and an input of energy."

      Example of energy-efficiency is conversion efficiency; the energy required divided by the energy consumed. It is important to note here that both input and output should be clearly specified in terms of quantity and quality and be measurable.

      Example of energy-efficiency is conversion efficiency; the energy required divided by the energy consumed. It is important to note here that both input and output should be clearly specified in terms of quantity and quality and be measurable.
    • Significant energy use (SEU) is defined as per clause 3.5.6 as "energy use accounting for substantial energy consumption and/or offering considerable potential for energy performance improvement".

      It is important to note here that Significance criteria are determined by the organization herself. SEUs can be facilities, systems, processes, or equipment.
      Significant energy use (SEU) is defined as per clause 3.5.6 as "energy use accounting for substantial energy consumption and/or offering considerable potential for energy performance improvement".

      It is important to note here that Significance criteria are determined by the organization herself. SEUs can be facilities, systems, processes, or equipment.

  • Energy Management
  • Energy management incorporates operations and planning functions of energy generation and energy usage & consumption units. Planning includes Energy Objectives, which are resource optimization to minimize the energy consumption patterns, and ultimately it leads to cost savings. The users have the required access to the energy they require but the optimization of energy is the core focus. 

    Energy management is also interrelated with environmental management system (See Alison's course on ISO 14001 - Environmental Management System), operations & production management system, supply chain systems and other developed business functions. Energy management system - EnMS is the proactive, collaborative and systematic cohesion of supply, conversion, distribution and utilization of energy to comply with the requirements, with the consideration of environmental and profitability objectives.

    One of the primary measures for well-planned energy optimization & control program; is the energy assessment of the baseline. This study critically examines the pattern of energy consumption at present by that specific organization. This study is crucially important to make the reference point for future improvements and making the organization energy efficient. Energy-efficient measures can enhance current energy consumption patterns.

  •  
     The key points from this module are:
  •  
    • The building energy management system is often referred to as BMS/BEMS. 
    • The analysis and monitoring system for energy is known as Energy Management Information System (EMIS). 
    • EnMS is a management system that empowers organizations to plan, review, improve, and identify improvements for the energy consumption patterns in an organization. 
    • Without EnMS, EMIS alone cannot do much on energy optimization. This is where the EnMS optimizes and utilizes EMIS investment. 
    • When there is a non-systematic approach to energy management, EMIS delivers no significant value unless the correct data is gathered and it is assessed and analyzed in the correct manner.
    • ISO 50001:2018 is the latest published international standard for Energy Management System (EnMS). It was published in August 2018.
    • ISO 50001:2018 specifies requirements for developing, applying, maintaining and continually improving an energy management system (EnMS).
    • An EnMS encompasses active management of energy into organization's management systems and daily procedures. The goal is to empower organizations to effectively manage their plan-do-check-act (PDCA) cycle on the basis of its energy usage, to attain savings in operating cost, and to continually boost energy performance and energy efficiency.

    • The building energy management system is often referred to as BMS/BEMS.

      The is the first sub-clause of Clause 4.       This is the second sub-clause of Clause 4. It is related to the identification and listing of interested parties and related information related to them. The organization shall identify:

      • The related needs and requirements of identified interested parties.
      • The listed needs and expectations which the organization addresses through its EnMS. The organization must do the following issues:
        • ascertains that it has access to the applicable legal requirements and other requirements concerning its energy application, energy efficiency,  and energy usage.

    • Incorporation of risk and opportunities are components of top and strategic decision-making in a company. By recognizing the risks and opportunities when reviewing the EnMS, a company can foresee the potential scenarios and outcomes so that unwanted consequences can be resolved before they happen. Likewise, beneficial prospects or situations that can provide potential benefits or positive outcomes can be recognized and opted for.
      Incorporation of risk and opportunities are components of top and strategic decision-making in a company. By recognizing the risks and opportunities when reviewing the EnMS, a company can foresee the potential scenarios and outcomes so that unwanted consequences can be resolved before they happen. Likewise, beneficial prospects or situations that can provide potential benefits or positive outcomes can be recognized and opted for.

    • This clause - 6.1.1 is part of the clause - 6.1. When planning for the EnMS, the organization needs to review the issues referred to in Clause - 4.1 and the requirements referred to in Clause -  4.2 (Read the topic on Context of Organization) and assess the organization’s measures and processes that can influence energy performance. Planning needs to be related to the energy policy and may lead to measures that will ultimately help in the continual improvement of energy performance. The organization needs to identify the risks and opportunities that need to be addressed to:

        • Provide confirmation that the EnMS can attain its planned results, including energy performance improvement.
        • Avoid or minimize the unwanted impact.
        • Attain continual improvement of energy performance and the EnMS.

    • Objectives can incorporate both high-level improvements to an EnMS and specific, measurable energy performance improvement targets. While some objectives will be measurable and have targets for energy performance improvement (e.g. minimize electricity consumption by five percentage by the end of the quarter, improve two percentage of the plant efficiency improvement by the end of year). Moreover, objectives can also be qualitative (e.g. concerning the energy-related cultural change and energy behaviour of the organization). It is also likely to attach some quantitative numbers for qualitative objectives, through surveys or any other formula. The organization needs to have documented information on the objectives and energy targets (for more information on documented information; check - 7.5).

      Clause - 6.2.1

      The organization needs to develop objectives at appropriate levels and functions. The organization needs to develop energy targets.

      Clause - 6.2.2

      The objectives and energy targets need to have the following elements:

      • It should be consistent with the energy policy (check - 5.2)
      • It should be measurable (if possible)
      • It should consider account applicable requirements
      • It should take into account the Significant energy uses - SEUs (check - 6.3)
      • It should consider account opportunities (check - 6.3) to improve energy performance.
      • It should be monitored
      • It should be communicated
      • It should be updated as needed.

      Incorporation of risk and opportunities are components of top and strategic decision-making in a company.     • Planning Elements for EnMS (Clause - 6.1.1)
      This clause - 6.1.1 is part of the clause - 6.1. When planning for the EnMS, the organization needs to review the issues referred to in Clause - 4.1 and the requirements referred to in Clause -  4.2 (Read the topic on Context of Organization) and assess the organization’s measures and processes that can influence energy performance. Planning needs to be related to the energy policy and may lead to measures that will ultimately help in the continual improvement of energy performance. The organization needs to identify the risks and opportunities that need to be addressed to:

        • Provide confirmation that the EnMS can attain its planned results, including energy performance improvement.
        • Avoid or minimize the unwanted impact.
        • Attain continual improvement of energy performance and the EnMS.

      This clause - 6.1.1 is part of the clause - 6.1. When planning for the EnMS, the organization needs to review the issues referred to in Clause - 4.1 and the requirements referred to in Clause -  4.2 (Read the topic on Context of Organization) and assess the organization’s measures and processes that can influence energy performance. Planning needs to be related to the energy policy and may lead to measures that will ultimately help in the continual improvement of energy performance. The organization needs to identify the risks and opportunities that need to be addressed to:

        • Provide confirmation that the EnMS can attain its planned results, including energy performance improvement.
        • Avoid or minimize the unwanted impact.
        • Attain continual improvement of energy performance and the EnMS.

    • Objectives can incorporate both high-level improvements to an EnMS and specific, measurable energy performance improvement targets. While some objectives will be measurable and have targets for energy performance improvement (e.g. minimize electricity consumption by five percentage by the end of the quarter, improve two percentage of the plant efficiency improvement by the end of year). Moreover, objectives can also be qualitative (e.g. concerning the energy-related cultural change and energy behaviour of the organization). It is also likely to attach some quantitative numbers for qualitative objectives, through surveys or any other formula. The organization needs to have documented information on the objectives and energy targets (for more information on documented information; check - 7.5).

      Clause - 6.2.1

      The organization needs to develop objectives at appropriate levels and functions. The organization needs to develop energy targets.

      Clause - 6.2.2

      The objectives and energy targets need to have the following elements:

      • It should be consistent with the energy policy (check - 5.2)
      • It should be measurable (if possible)
      • It should consider account applicable requirements
      • It should take into account the Significant energy uses - SEUs (check - 6.3)
      • It should consider account opportunities (check - 6.3) to improve energy performance.
      • It should be monitored
      • It should be communicated
      • It should be updated as needed.

    • Under clause - 6.2.3, when planning how to achieve its objectives and energy targets, the organization needs to develop and keep plans for action. It can have the following elements:

      • What will be done
      • What resources will be needed
      • Who will be liable for actions
      • When it will be done
      • How the results will be assessed, together with the methods utilized to confirm energy performance improvement (check clause - 9.1).

While some objectives will be measurable and have targets for energy performance improvement (e.g. minimize electricity consumption by five percentage by the end of the quarter, improve two percentage of the plant efficiency improvement by the end of year). Moreover, objectives can also be qualitative (e.g. concerning the energy-related cultural change and energy behaviour of the organization). It is also likely to attach some quantitative numbers for qualitative objectives, through surveys or any other formula. The organization needs to have documented information on the objectives and energy targets (for more information on documented information; check - 7.5).

      Clause - 6.2.1

      The organization needs to develop objectives at appropriate levels and functions. The organization needs to develop energy targets.

      The objectives and energy targets need to have the following elements:

      • It should be measurable (if possible)
      • It should consider account applicable requirements
      • It should take into account the Significant energy uses - SEUs (check - 6.3)
      • It should consider account opportunities (check - 6.3) to improve energy performance.
      • It should be monitored
      • It should be communicated
      • It should be updated as needed.

    • Actions related to Risks & Opportunities (Clause -6.1)
      Incorporation of risk and opportunities are components of top and strategic decision-making in a company. By recognizing the risks and opportunities when reviewing the EnMS, a company can foresee the potential scenarios and outcomes so that unwanted consequences can be resolved before they happen. Likewise, beneficial prospects or situations that can provide potential benefits or positive outcomes can be recognized and opted for.

    • Planning Elements for EnMS (Clause - 6.1.1)
      This clause - 6.1.1 is part of the clause - 6.1. When planning for the EnMS, the organization needs to review the issues referred to in Clause - 4.1 and the requirements referred to in Clause -  4.2 (Read the topic on Context of Organization) and assess the organization’s measures and processes that can influence energy performance. Planning needs to be related to the energy policy and may lead to measures that will ultimately help in the continual improvement of energy performance. The organization needs to identify the risks and opportunities that need to be addressed to:

        • Provide confirmation that the EnMS can attain its planned results, including energy performance improvement.
        • Avoid or minimize the unwanted impact.
        • Attain continual improvement of energy performance and the EnMS.

  •  The key points from this module are:
  • 1
    • Context of the organization is a new requirement in ISO 50001:2018 standard.
    • Understanding the Organization's Context (Clause -  4.1); is about identifying external and internal issues for the energy management system which can affect the EnMS or can be affected the performance of EnMS. 
    • Understanding Interested Parties' Needs and Expectations (Clause - 4.2); It is related to the identification and listing of interested parties and related information related to them.
    • Identifying the EnMS Scope (Clause - 4.3);  is related to the determination of EnMS scope. There is a restriction in the standard here; the organization cannot exclude any energy type from its scope and boundaries. 
    • Culture & Maturity for Energy Management is the example of an internal issue for an organization.
    • Limitations of energy supply is an external issue for an organization. 
    • As an organization, EnMS needs to demonstrate improvement in some areas and not all areas. It does necessarily means that all the Energy Performance Indicators (EnPIs) will be improved, some EnPIs will somehow show improvement while others will not.

      The company needs to identify energy performance and improvement in EnMS by taking care of the following:

      • Energy-related issues which need to be measured and monitored, along with a minimal list of the following main qualities:
            • The success or effectiveness of the action plans in attaining energy objectives and targets
            • The Energy Performance Indicators - EnPIs
            • Operation of Signification Energy Use - SEUs
            • Actual versus expected energy use and consumption
      • The methods for analysis, monitoring, measurement and evaluation, as relevant, to make sure valid results.
      • The time of the monitoring and measurement needs to be performed.
      • The time when the results from monitoring and measurement need to be analyzed and evaluated.

    • This clause incorporates the application of the data collection plan (check clause - 6.6) and assessment of both energy performance improvement and effectiveness of the EnMS.

      Effectiveness of the EnMS can be proven by improvement in energy performance and other intended outcomes. Energy performance improvement can be demonstrated by improvements in EnPI values over time, relative to the corresponding EnB. There can be instances where energy performance improvement is attained from a proceeding that is not associated to an SEU or key quality characteristic. In those examples, an EnPI and EnB can be developed to show energy performance improvement.

      When performing analysis, the usual restrictions for the data (examples are measurement uncertainty, accuracy and precision) and consistency of energy-related reporting should be considered before reaching ultimate conclusions.

  • Internal Audit (Clause - 9.2)
  • Internal audits of an EnMS can be performed by workers of the company, or by outsourced professionals appointed by the company and their work on its behalf. Auditor independence can be demonstrated by an auditor being free from responsibility for the activity being audited. An energy audit or energy assessment is not the same concept as an internal audit of an EnMS. The clause - 9.2 is related to Internal audit, it has two sub-clauses.

    • Requirements on Internal Audits (Clause - 9.2.1)
      As per clause - 9.2.1, the organization needs to perform internal audits of the EnMS at designated and designed intervals to offer the following important information on the EnMS:
      • The EnMS Enhances energy performance
      • The EnMS Conforms to:
          • the company's own requirements for its EnMS;
          • the energy policy (check clause - 5.2), objectives and energy targets (check clause - 6.2) developed by the company.
          • the requirements of ISO 50001:2018 standard
      • The EnMS is robustly applied and maintained.

    • Requirements on Internal Audits (Clause - 9.2.2)
      In clause - 9.2.2, the organization needs to do the following:
      • Plan, develop, apply and keep audit programs together with its methods, frequency, responsibilities, requirements for planning and reporting, which shall take into account the importance of the concerned processes and the outcomes of earlier EnMS audits.
      • Identify the audit criteria and explicate scope for each EnMS audit.
      • Appoint auditors from organization or elsewhere and perform audits to make sure objectivity and the neutrality of the audit process.
      • Ascertains that the audit results are reported timely to management.
      • Initiate relevant actions in accordance with check clause -10.1 and clause -10.2
      • Keep documented information (check clause - 7.5) as proof of the implementation of the audit programs and the audit results.

     The key points from this module are:
  • 1
    • Clause - 9.1.1 incorporates the application of the data collection plan and assessment of both energy performance improvement and effectiveness of the EnMS.
    • Effectiveness of the EnMS can be proven by improvement in energy performance and other intended outcomes. 
    • Energy performance improvement can be demonstrated by improvements in EnPI values over time, relative to the corresponding EnB. 
    • When performing analysis, the usual restrictions for the data (examples are measurement uncertainty, accuracy and precision) and consistency of energy-related reporting should be considered before reaching ultimate conclusions.
    • The Clause - 9.1.2 is related to the evaluation of compliance and titled as "Evaluation of compliance with legal requirements and other requirements". 
    • At planned intervals, the organization needs to assess compliance with legal and other requirements pertinent to its energy use and consumption,  energy efficiency and the EnMS.
